importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: This is when the fraudulent call involving Defence Minister Guido Crosetto was reportedly made, marking the beginning of a high-profile AI voice fraud incident in Italy.
Crosetto publicly addressed the scam on X, stating he had received a call from a 'friend' and was later contacted by a businessman who made a large transfer after a call from a 'General'.
The article notes a broader trend of deepfake scams rising from $200 million in the first quarter to $347 million in the second quarter of the year, indicating a growing global threat.
Resemble AI released a report in July showing that advances in AI have led to the industrialized production of AI-generated child sexual abuse material, prompting global law enforcement concern.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Between January and June 2025, over $547 million was lost globally to deepfake scams, showing a sharp upward trend in AI-powered fraud.

keyTakeAways: AI-generated voices are now indistinguishable from real human voices in many cases, particularly when cloned from real individuals.
The Italian government scam involving Defence Minister Guido Crosetto demonstrates how deepfake voice technology is being used to manipulate wealthy individuals into transferring money.
AI voice cloning uses deep learning and natural language processing to mimic pitch, accent, intonation, and speech patterns with increasing realism.

Research from Queen Mary University of London found that 41% of AI-generated voices and 58% of voice clones were mistaken for real human voices, and participants often rated AI voices as more trustworthy.
Deepfake technologies are being used to create fraudulent calls, fake news, and sexually explicit content, including AI-generated child sexual abuse material.

Global law enforcement is reacting with new legislation, such as the U.S. law criminalizing the publication of AI-generated intimate images without consent and Australia banning a key deepfake application.
Despite risks, AI-generated voices also have positive applications, such as restoring voices for people who can no longer speak.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A sophisticated AI voice scam targeted wealthy Italian businessmen in early 2025, with fraudsters using deepfake technology to mimic the voice of Defence Minister Guido Crosetto and request large financial transfers. The scam, which involved fake calls from a 'General' and a cloned voice of Crosetto, led to one businessman, Massimo Moratti, making a transfer that was later frozen by authorities. Research by Queen Mary University of London shows that AI-generated voice clones are now indistinguishable from real human voices in many cases, with participants often perceiving them as more trustworthy. Global losses from similar scams have surged to over $547 million between January and June 2025, and AI-generated content, including child sexual abuse material, has become a major concern. In response, the U.S. and Australia have introduced new laws banning the creation and distribution of AI-generated intimate images. While AI voice technology offers benefits such as helping individuals who cannot speak, its misuse in scams and deepfakes poses serious ethical and security risks to individuals and societies.
title: AI now sounds more like us – should we be concerned?
